Dear Dr. Miller:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Education
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4123
Section (2) Provision shall be made for an appropriate education program
Description in accordance with 1976 PA 451, MCL 380.1 to 380.1853. Each
resident of school age shall be enrolled not later than 5 school
days after admission and continuously thereafter.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency is not providing proper education.
Investigation Interviews:
On 8/5/2024 DCWL Program Manager received information from
Complainant regarding concerns that youth at Havenwyck were
behind in credits due to not following the Michigan Merit
Curriculum. In addition, youth at the facility did not have Individual
Education Plans (IEPs) as required. Complainant further reported
the school on-site at the facility was not registered as a non-public
school and did not use the public school system. The facility did
not hold regular credit reviews to ensure youth had the proper
amount to graduate timely and the program did not graduate
youth. Due to these concerns a complaint was also filed with
Michigan Department of Education (MDE). Due to the
investigation with MDE, Program Manager determined the
investigation by DCWL would be completed once MDE
determined their findings.
Complainant reported to DCWL via email on 10/7/24 that MDE
extended their investigation through the end of the month. It was
clarified that the MDE investigation was focused on the local
school district and their role in providing education to the youth at
the facility.
Education Analyst was contacted on 11/13/24 and reported the
MDE investigation was complete. Education Analyst stated the
local school district was found in violation and placed on a
corrective action plan due to special education students not
receiving a proper education at the facility. Education Analyst
stated they continued to have concerns that the facility was not
following Michigan Merit Curriculum for youth to receive credits
2

and graduate. Education Analyst reported that it was their
understanding that the school at Havenwyck did not issue
diplomas at graduation. When youth left the program, they needed
to have their new school complete the audit and issue a diploma.
MDE Education Consultant was contacted via email on
11/26/25. Education Consultant confirmed that youth at the facility
were enrolled in Havenwyck School, which was a non-public
school. The MDE investigation corrective action plan required a
plan to provide all eligible current and future students with
disabilities a Free Appropriate Public Education (FAPE) as
required under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act
(IDEA), which includes completion of IEPs. Meetings were
scheduled between MDE, Havenwyck, and DCWL to discuss
plans to ensure the required education was provided.
Meetings occurred on 12/11/24, 12/17/24, and 1/7/25 with Chief
Administrator, Education Consultant, Havenwyck Chief
Executive Officer, DCWL, and local public-school administration.
It was discussed that youth at the facility were enrolled in a private
school. However, due to youth being placed in foster care, they
were required to receive the same benefits as public school
students. Due to a reported misunderstanding of the type of youth
placed, the local school district was not completing IEPs or
providing services. Teachers at Havenwyck school were not
special education certified to provide those services. When youth
were discharged from the facility, they received a transcript. If
youth finished school while at the facility, they could not graduate
as the school was not accredited. In addition, youth only attended
school from 7:30-11:30AM, which was not sufficient to meet
educational requirements by MDE. It was determined the facility
would explore online education programs through a public school
district, in order to meet requirements. The local school district
and facility staff collaborated to determine which youth needed a
current IEP. It was determined the facility would begin to utilize an
accredited online school in collaboration with the Intermediate
School District (ISD), in order to begin providing education to
youth that met FAPE and IDEA requirements.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
on 1/8/25. Chief Administrator reported the facility did not have the
proper special education services in place, due to the local school
district not providing the proper support. Chief Administrator
reported the school district lost several support staff and did not
complete IEPs as needed. Chief Administrator stated they had
frequent communication with the school district regarding their
3

needs. However, the school district was not responsive. Chief
Administrator clarified that the teachers at the facility were
Havenwyck employees, not teachers associated with a school
district.
Teacher 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/8/25.
Teacher 1 reported they struggled to work with the local school
district, to coordinate services. The school district frequently did
not have paperwork updated to send with youth when they left the
facility and enrolled in another school. Teacher 1 reported the
school district had never been in compliance with IEPs and none
had been completed. Teacher 1 stated they complete enrollment
forms and document the need for IEPs, then send the information
to the school district. However, the school district never followed
up with requests by the facility. Teacher 1 reported the school at
the facility was a non-public school. Teacher 1 stated they did not
have any issues with credits transferring to other schools.
Teacher 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/8/25.
Teacher 2 reported they worked with the local school district to
enroll youth and request IEPs. However, the school district did not
do their part, as determined by the MDE investigation. Teacher 2
stated they had frequent communication with the school district
regarding needs for the youth, but the district never responded.
Teacher 2 was aware that Chief Administrator also reached out to
the district to request a meeting to develop a more cooperative
relationship, but the district did not respond. Teacher 2 provided
documentation of enrollment forms and emails to confirm they
completed the enrollment process as required.
Documents reviewed:
• Email dated 2/27/24 between Education Analyst and
District Teacher Consultant. The District Teacher
Consultant confirmed youth at the facility would receive
non-public Service Plans, not IEPs.
• Emails between Teacher 1 and the school district from
1/30/24, 2/7/24, 3/20/24, 4/8/24, 9/5/24, and 9/11/24 were
reviewed. Teacher 1 notified the district of youth enrollment
forms that were submitted and requested IEP/service plans
for youth.
• Education records for youth placed at the facility were
reviewed and determined school enrollment forms were
completed by Havenwyck and provided to the school
district within five school days of admission.
• A list of youth from the facility identified eight youth
currently in need of an IEP.
4

• MDE complaint 24-0188 decision dated 10/20/24. The
investigation concluded the school district failed to fulfill its
obligation to the students at the facility. Information from
the decision, relevant to the DCWL investigation included:
• Havenwyck’s on-site school was determined to be a
private school, located in the boundaries of Oakland
Schools Intermediate School District (ISD).
• The ISD noted ten students in need of educational
service plan reevaluations during the 2022-2023
school year.
• Multidisciplinary Evaluation Team report was
initiated for each student. However, the reports were
not completed. In addition, the reports identified the
youth’s MDHHS caseworker as the parent/guardian.
However, the definition of a parent prohibits the state
(MDHHS) from serving as the IDEA parent for
special education decision making purposes. If the
child is a state ward, a parent or appointed surrogate
parent, must be involved in IDEA.
• The district identified eleven students as having
been referred to the district for the 2023-2024 school
year. Registration for the students was completed on
10/4/23.
• There was no documentation to support that the
school district completed comprehensive
reevaluations for students at Havenwyck during the
2023-2024 school year.
• There was no evidence to indicate the ISD provided
any assistance or support to the school district to
ensure that students at Havenwyck’s private school
were evaluated or provided FAPE.
• MDE complaint 24-0190 decision dated 10/20/24. The
investigation concluded the following:
• None of the students at Havenwyck were enrolled in
the private school by a parent. All students were
under the care and custody of MDHHS. Therefore,
none of the parentally placed private school
students’ provisions apply.
• The district treated the private school students as
parentally placed with respect to Child Find and the
provision of equitable services. However, Child Find
efforts were incomplete as no evaluations were
completed during the 2023-2024 school year.
• MDE Office of Special Education “failed to ensure
that the educational programs at the (Havenwyck)
5

private school were under the general supervision of
MDE”.
Analysis A violation was found as the facility utilized an on-site private
school for youth in care. Licensing rules require compliance with
1976 PA 451, MCL 380.1 to 380.1853, which states that students
with disabilities placed by a public entity (MDHHS), need to be
enrolled in a public school that provides a Free Appropriate Public
Education (FAPE) and follow all special education laws. As
students at the facility did not receive a public education, students
also did not receive special education services and Individual
Education Plans.
Technical Assistance
Technical assistance was offered that in the future should the
local school district not respond, Havenwyck should contact the
Michigan Department of Education in order to ensure youth
services are put in place timely.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
